
## How to visually check continuous variables?{.center}

## Histograms

```{r}
#| echo: true
#| warning: false
#| output-location: default

library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)

data("penguins")
penguins %>% 
group_by(species) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=bill_length_mm, color=species, fill=species))+
  geom_histogram()

```

## Boxplots

```{r}
#| echo: true
#| warning: false
#| output-location: column

library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)

data("penguins")
penguins %>% 
group_by(species) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=species, 
             y=bill_length_mm, 
             color=species, 
             fill=species))+
  geom_boxplot(alpha=0.5)+
  theme(axis.text=element_text(size=16),
        axis.title=element_text(size=16))

```


## Your turn

## Checking categorical varibles{.center}

## Species of penguin

```{r}
#| echo: true
#| warning: false
#| output-location: column

library(tidyverse)
library(palmerpenguins)

penguins %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=species,
             color=species, 
             fill=species))+
  geom_bar(alpha=0.5)+
  theme(axis.text=element_text(size=16),
        axis.title=element_text(size=16))

```

## Visualising correlations


```{r}

#| warning: false
#| output-location: column

  ggplot(aes(x=bill_length_mm, 
             y = bill_depth_mm))+
  geom_point()+
  theme(axis.text=element_text(size=16),
        axis.title=element_text(size=16))

```

## Boddy mass per sex

```{r}
#| echo: true
#| warning: false
#| output-location: column

penguins %>% 
  na.omit() %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=sex, 
             y = body_mass_g,
             color=species, 
             fill=species))+
  geom_boxplot(alpha=0.7)+
  theme(axis.text=element_text(size=16),
        axis.title=element_text(size=16))

```

## Boddy mass per sex (iverting groups)

```{r}
#| echo: true
#| warning: false
#| output-location: column

penguins %>% 
  na.omit() %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=species, 
             y = body_mass_g,
             color=sex, 
             fill=sex))+
  geom_boxplot(alpha=0.7)+
  theme(axis.text=element_text(size=16),
        axis.title=element_text(size=16))

```

## Exploring data is asking relevant questions

- This is not mining 
- Don't just correlate random things
- Start to imagine before coding

## Visualization can always be better

```{r}
#| echo: true
#| warning: false
#| output-location: column

penguins %>% 
  na.omit() %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=species, 
             y = body_mass_g,
         group=sex,
         fill=sex,
         color=sex))+
  geom_jitter()+
  
  theme(axis.text=element_text(size=16),
        axis.title=element_text(size=16))

```
